Do we know?  You know.  He's fine.  Today, it's my great honor to sign the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Act into law.  Everyday America's adversaries are testing our cyber defenses.  They attempt to gain access to our critical infrastructure, exploit our great companies, and undermine our entire way of life.  and we can't let that happen.  This vital legislation will establish a new agency within the Department of Homeland Security to lead the federal government's civilian response to these cyber threats against our nation.  We've had many, many threats against our nation.  Cyber is gonna be the newest form, and the threats have taken place, and we've been doing pretty good at knocking them out, but now this will make us, I think, much more effective.  The men and women of the new Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency will be on the front lines of our cyber defense.  They will partner with the private sector and all levels of government to defend America's power grids, banks, telecommunications, and other critical parts of our economy.  The cyber battle space evolves, and it is evolving, and unfortunately, faster than a lot of people want to talk about, but battle space it is.  So as the cyber battle space evolves, this new agency will ensure that we confront the full range of threats from nation states, cyber criminals, and other malicious actors, of which there are many.

There is so much news that happened while everybody was sleeping because this highly anticipated second summit between President Trump and Kim Jong-un ended abruptly.  That's right.  It's over.  And there was no deal to curb North Korea's nuclear weapons program.  The two leaders met in Hanoi, Vietnam, for several hours earlier in the day.  And then at a news conference with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, a visibly deflated president said he and Kim made progress, but not enough.  to sign any kind of agreement.
Sometimes you have to walk.

It was a high-stakes meeting with a disappointing outcome.  After extensive face-to-face talks in a five-star Hanoi hotel, President Trump said Kim Jong Un's offer was simply not good enough to give up America's leverage.

They basically established footholds in the Chinese region, and they apparently established footholds in the Malaysian region.  The Times reports the NSA began spying on North Korea's computer networks after becoming increasingly concerned that the regime was bolstering its teams of hackers.  Kim Jong-un's government has a secretive hacking team called Bureau 121 and a larger cyber branch called the Reconnaissance General Bureau.
CBS's Major Garrett asked the president about lifting sanctions.

Basically, they wanted the sanctions lifted in their entirety, and we couldn't do that.  They were willing to denuke a large portion of the areas that we wanted, but we couldn't give up all of the sanctions for that.
Will all the sanctions that are currently in existence remain, sir?
They're in place.  You know, I was watching as a lot of you folks over the weeks have said, oh, we've given up.  We haven't given up anything.

I'm also curious not only what you think happened overnight there, but also what the implications are in terms of the U.S.-China trade deal and our relationship with China as President Xi has been watching all of this.

Well, the deal fell apart along what we have seen the deals fall apart in the past over, which was sequencing, right?  We know that from the special envoy to North Korea that was appointed by the United States, he made a speech at Stanford in January, and he said that the North Koreans had agreed to dismantle their uranium and plutonium enrichment facilities.  So that was the care that they were dangling out, and they wanted to see what the United States would give them to do that.  So that's why they ended up here in Hanoi.  The fact is, the North Koreans wanted way more than what the United States was willing to give, hence why the president walked away.  They clearly want all the sanctions lifted.  The president was very specific about that.  We now know that all this discussion about, oh, is President Trump going to give up troops in South Korea as a concession to Kim Jong-un?  Now it's pretty clear, I'm not sure Kim Jong-un really is all interested in all of that.  And that was never on the table in the first place.  so the president walked away.  what does this mean for the the china?  uh... situation the tried china negotiations.  look i take the president and secretary pompeo at face value that they were not satisfied with this deal.  i think there is a secondary benefit to the president that it sends a signaling message to the chinese that they will walk away from a deal that they're if if if he doesn't like the terms he's not so eager to have a win that hill.  take anything.  so But I don't think that's the primary motivation about why they walked away from this deal with North Korea.  I think the primary motivation was that they didn't like the terms.

Russian hacking to influence the American election has dominated the news, but we've also noticed a hacking attack that could be a future menace to America.  Well, China is stealing our military secrets.  New research suggests Chinese hackers are targeting more than two dozen universities to get access to maritime technology.  To trusted SEC founder and cybersecurity expert David Kennedy.  David, do you have any doubt that this is being done by the military, the Chinese military?

I mean, we don't have a lot of the data to actually support exactly where it came from, but we have seen a huge increase in Chinese government activity related to this type of theft.  So, I mean, if they're saying it came from China, there's probably a lot of great evidence to support it.  And I wouldn't doubt it.  There's been a huge uptick.  a substantial amount since 2015 when we actually had a treaty that really set forth that we wouldn't see a lot of this intellectual property theft.  So there's not really much doubt in our minds around where it's originating from.  And we're definitely seeing a huge increase when it comes to intellectual property theft, government secret theft from the Chinese government specifically.
Do we know what they're looking for?

Well, in this specific case, they were developing maritime technology to be used for military purposes.  And China definitely uses this type of cyber theft to go into different organizations or different types of research facilities to ensure that it can keep up to date with what the United States is doing.  And we see that very commonly from different intelligence organizations, including Russia, including North Korea, including Iran.  All of these are different ways that we can use cyber capabilities to understand what our adversaries are doing.  And China definitely does that same thing.  They want to understand the technology that we're developing so they can stay up to speed with what we're doing here with our military as well.

Now, clearly, they want us out of Asia.  I mean, they want us out of all of Asia.  They want to be the dominant force in Asia.  They don't want us to be any part of it.  But specifically the South China Sea, isn't that their real target here?  That's where they have those islands built up, et cetera.

And that's been a major contention point between the United States and our allies when it comes to that specific geographic location.  And so when it comes to maritime technology, are we building up our capabilities to try to have an advantage in those locations?  That's definitely something that China is very interested in and wants to ensure that they maintain a very big presence in that disputed area.  So it's definitely something that I can see where they'd want to have access to that facility.  And we see that commonly.  Medical research is a huge area for them.  Military preparedness is a huge area for them.  They're definitely increasing their sophistication and the amount of intrusions they have here within the United States, and especially during these trade war battles.

But we begin with late news on the defense secretary.  One day after the president said he's pulling U.S.  troops out of Syria, Mr.  Trump tweeted General Jim Mattis will be retiring with distinction at the end of February after having served my administration as Secretary of Defense for the past two years.  Warning about our electrical grid.  Experts say that Russian hackers found a way to hack our utilities and the hackers may still be in there waiting to strike.  That sounds ominous, doesn't it?  Van Hip is with us, American Defence International Chair.  Van, that is an ominous statement.  I mean, if they've hacked in and they're still in and we don't know exactly where they are, I mean, could they bring down the whole grid?

Very serious.  You know, Sudhaf said that the cyber war is the fifth dimension of warfare.  Whoever wins the cyber war will win the next major military operation.  I think what we are seeing the Russians doing is this, though.  I call it more of a probing attack.  They're gathering intelligence.  They're prepping the battlefield for something more sinister.  You talk about taking down the grid.  There are three ways to attack the grid.  I think it's very important that people understand this.  One is a cyber attack.  One is an electromagnetic pulse attack.  And the other is a Carrington event, a geomagnetic storm in the face of the sun.  Well, Stuart, we had one of those back in 1859.  And we were OK.  But you know what?  The American farmer could feed the American people and grow enough food in 1859 without electricity.  The American farmer cannot do that today.  That's why this is so critical.  And oh, by the way, NASA says, Stuart, in the next 10 to 100 years, we will have another Carrington event.

After careful investigation, the United States is publicly attributing the massive WannaCry cyber attack to North Korea.  We do not make this allegation lightly.  We do so with evidence, and we do so with partners.  Other governments and private companies agree.  The United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and Japan have seen our analysis, and they join us in denouncing North Korea for WannaCry.

The Trump administration has eliminated its cybersecurity rather coordinator role in a move that really has puzzled a lot of experts.  Rob Joyce announced that he was leaving the post to return to the National Security Agency last month and he will not be replaced.  You see all these people departing, Secretary Mattis, Chief of Staff John Kelly, Secretary Tillerson.  Help put this in perspective.  All right.  On the crazy scale, how crazy is this?

You know, Hoda, it's a shame that there's been this sense, and I think some people that watch, I'm sure, the Today Show thinks sometimes, you know, you say it's a crisis, you say it's a crisis.  It's a shame people might be so numb to this, and some of us are so numb.  I can't underscore how serious things are right now.

Let's bring in right now Riley Walters of the Heritage Foundation to talk about this.  And look, you know, there's been a lot of speculation.  markets have been steadily rising on hopes of a deal.  But is this going to be a good deal, Riley, from what we know?

You're right.  I mean, certainly the devil's in the details for this trade deal.  What it's looking like is we might have a deal set by the end of March, but the question is whether tariffs will continue to still be around at the end of March, whether perhaps the tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports will remain, or perhaps all $250 billion worth of goods that are currently tariffed will be removed.  I think for sure, what markets are hopeful and what a lot of Americans would like to?

It's the U.S.  intelligence community's worldwide threat assessment.  And I just want to direct your attention to the real doozy that starts on the bottom of page five.  Quote, China has the ability to launch cyber attacks that cause localized temporary disruptive effects on American critical infrastructure, such as disruption of a natural gas pipeline for days to weeks in the United States.  Oh, and it's not just China.  Go to page six.  Quote, Russia has the ability to execute cyber attacks in the United States that generate localized temporary disruptive effects on critical infrastructure, such as disrupting an electrical distribution network for at least a few hours.  So China could shut off the natural gas pipelines.  Russia can just shut off the electricity.  They have that ability now.

The warning went out late Friday by email from the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security.  And as you say, it is being called a rare public warning by those groups.  The attacks are by a sophisticated set of actors.  Not clear exactly who's behind this.  And they began in May.  Here's what we know about which specific sectors are being targeted.  And as you say, it's a very long list here.  starting with nuclear, energy, aviation, water, and critical manufacturing, all being targeted by this mysterious hacking group that the government says has been active for several months and has penetrated some of those networks.  What do we know about?  who is behind this?  Not much definitively, but the cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike has said that they believe that this could be an entity they are calling Berserk Bear, which they say is affiliated with the Russian Federation.  And experts have said that what they're seeing here is aggressive activity, but no destructive action yet.  And they say that this campaign is still ongoing.  So it looks like what you've got here is an elaborate probe operation going into all of these sensitive industries in which the hackers are determined to figure out how those industries' networks work, maintain a maybe permanent presence in them.  To what end, though, is unclear.  Is this sort of a just-in-case kind of preparation for total war that intelligence agencies go through all the time, or is this the precursor to some more subtle, more narrow attack that could happen in the near future?  Not clear at all necessarily where this is going, but the US government wants people in those industries to know that this is happening and to take steps to stop it, guys.
